Ow Saturday Dr. Macdonald, M.P., held an inquiry
at the Vestry Hall, Church-row, Bethnal Green,
respecting the death of Kathleen King, aged forty,
the wife of William Hing, a labourer, of 43, Half
Nichol-street, Bethnal Green, who died on Wednes-
day. Annie Hockins deposed that deceased worked
at Grace's Lead Works, Bethnal Green-road, and
lodged with her. Some weeks ago deceased was in
the hospital, suffering from the effects of lead poison-
ing. She returned to her work, but continually com-
plained of illness after. On Sunday she had a fit.
Witness advised her husband not to let her go back to
the works, He said he would not. On Wednesday she
was called to deceased by a neighbour. On going into
the bedroom she found deceased in bed, her head hang-
ing over the aide. Martha Kilby, of 2, Catherine-
buildings, deposed that she was called by the last
witness. Seeing she was very ill and unconscious,
she ran for a doctor, but she died shortly after his
arrival. Mary Brown stated that she lived in the
same house as deceased. She knew she had been to
the hospital to be treated for lead poisoning. Dr.
Lewis Paton, of the Mildmay Mission, deposed to
being called on Wednesday tc deceased about
five p.m. She was unconscious and breathing hard.
He tried artificial respiration, which was of no avail.
She died about six o'clock. The cause of death
was epilectic convulsions from chronic lead poison-
ing. The jury returned a verdict in accordance
with that of the medical evidence. A repre-
sentative of the firm where the deceased was
employed being present, stated, in reply to the
coroner, that every precaution was taken with regard
to cleanliness. A bath-room was properly fitted up
for the employés. A doctor went round and ex-
amined everyone on Fridays, but they found a great
difficulty to get the people to be clean—in fact, the
deceased hid herself on the last occasion to escape
examination, The coroner said he had no doubt
every precaution had been taken by the firm. When
lead once got into the system people employed in this
class of work should never go to it again, as it was
sure to eventually prove fatal : -

A Centra News telegram from New York says :—
A sad accident cnounied in Fairmount Park. Two
men and two women were in a rowing boat on an
artificial lake in the park, when they allowed tho
craft to drift too near a dam over which there was a
strong flow of water. The boat was carried over the
fall, and all its occupants drowned.
